article:
'Chief Rabbi' is a title given in several countries to the recognised religious
leader of that country's Jewish community, or to a rabbinic leader appointed by
the local secular authorities. Since 1911, through a capitulation by Rabbi
Uziel, Israel has had two chief rabbis, one Ashkenazi and one
Sephardi.

Cities with large Jewish communities may also have their own chief rabbis; this
is especially the case in Israel but has also been past practice in major Jewish
centers in Europe prior to the Holocaust. North American cities rarely have
chief rabbis. One exception however is Montreal, with twoâone for the Ashkenazi
community, the other for the Sephardi.

The Chief Rabbi's name is often followed by ABD, which stands for Av Beth Din.
